Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderVerify.name: accessToken
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderVerify.abstract: A valid access token that Amazon Cognito issued to the user whose user attributes you want to verify.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderVerify.name: attributeName
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderVerify.abstract: The attribute name in the request to verify user attributes.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderVerify.name: code
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderVerify.abstract: The verification code in the request to verify user attributes.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderVerify.name: session
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderVerify.abstract: The session that should be passed both ways in challenge-response calls to the service.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderVerify.name: status
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderVerify.abstract: The status of the verify software token.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderVerify.name: accessToken
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderVerify.abstract: A valid access token that Amazon Cognito issued to the user whose software token you want to verify.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderVerify.name: session
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderVerify.abstract: The session that should be passed both ways in challenge-response calls to the service.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderVerify.name: userCode
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderVerify.abstract: The one- time password computed using the secret code returned by AssociateSoftwareToken.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderVerifi.name: emailMessage
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderVerifi.abstract: The template for email messages that Amazon Cognito sends to your users. You can set an EmailMessage template only if the value of EmailSendingAccount is DEVELOPER. When your EmailSendingAccount is DEVELOPER, your user pool sends email messages with your own Amazon SES configuration.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderVerifi.name: emailMessageByLink
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderVerifi.abstract: The email message template for sending a confirmation link to the user. You can set an EmailMessageByLink template only if the value of EmailSendingAccount is DEVELOPER. When your EmailSendingAccount is DEVELOPER, your user pool sends email messages with your own Amazon SES configuration.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderVerifi.name: emailSubject
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderVerifi.abstract: The subject line for the email message template. You can set an EmailSubject template only if the value of EmailSendingAccount is DEVELOPER. When your EmailSendingAccount is DEVELOPER, your user pool sends email messages with your own Amazon SES configuration.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderVerifi.name: emailSubjectByLink
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderVerifi.abstract: The subject line for the email message template for sending a confirmation link to the user. You can set an EmailSubjectByLink template only if the value of EmailSendingAccount is DEVELOPER. When your EmailSendingAccount is DEVELOPER, your user pool sends email messages with your own Amazon SES configuration.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderVerifi.name: smsMessage
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderVerifi.abstract: The template for SMS messages that Amazon Cognito sends to your users.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserna.name: caseSensitive
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserna.abstract:
Specifies whether user name case sensitivity will be applied for all users in the user pool through Amazon Cognito APIs. For most use cases, set case sensitivity to False (case insensitive) as a best practice. When usernames and email addresses are case insensitive, users can sign in as the same user when they enter a different capitalization of their user name.

Valid values include:

True

Enables case sensitivity for all username input. When this option is set to True, users must sign in using the exact capitalization of their given username, such as “UserName”. This is the default value.

False

Enables case insensitivity for all username input. For example, when this option is set to False, users can sign in using username, USERNAME, or UserName. This option also enables both preferred_username and email alias to be case insensitive, in addition to the username attribute.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserTy.name: attributes
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserTy.abstract: A container with information about the user type attributes.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserTy.name: userLastModifiedDate
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserTy.abstract: The date and time, in ISO 8601 format, when the item was modified.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserTy.name: userStatus
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserTy.abstract:
The user status. This can be one of the following:

  • UNCONFIRMED - User has been created but not confirmed.

  • CONFIRMED - User has been confirmed.

  • EXTERNAL_PROVIDER - User signed in with a third-party IdP.

  • UNKNOWN - User status isn’t known.

  • RESET_REQUIRED - User is confirmed, but the user must request a code and reset their password before they can sign in.

  • FORCE_CHANGE_PASSWORD - The user is confirmed and the user can sign in using a temporary password, but on first sign-in, the user must change their password to a new value before doing anything else.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserTy.name: username
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserTy.abstract: The user name of the user you want to describe.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.name: accountRecoverySetting
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.abstract: The available verified method a user can use to recover their password when they call ForgotPassword. You can use this setting to define a preferred method when a user has more than one method available. With this setting, SMS doesn’t qualify for a valid password recovery mechanism if the user also has SMS multi-factor authentication (MFA) activated. In the absence of this setting, Amazon Cognito uses the legacy behavior to determine the recovery method where SMS is preferred through email.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.name: adminCreateUserConfig
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.abstract: The configuration for AdminCreateUser requests.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.name: aliasAttributes
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.abstract: The attributes that are aliased in a user pool.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.name: arn
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.abstract: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) for the user pool.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.name: autoVerifiedAttributes
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.abstract: The attributes that are auto-verified in a user pool.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.name: creationDate
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.abstract: The date and time, in ISO 8601 format, when the item was created.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.name: customDomain
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.abstract:
A custom domain name that you provide to Amazon Cognito. This parameter applies only if you use a custom domain to host the sign-up and sign-in pages for your application. An example of a custom domain name might be auth.example.com.

For more information about adding a custom domain to your user pool, see Using Your Own Domain for the Hosted UI.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.name: deletionProtection
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.abstract:
When active, DeletionProtection prevents accidental deletion of your user pool. Before you can delete a user pool that you have protected against deletion, you must deactivate this feature.

When you try to delete a protected user pool in a DeleteUserPool API request, Amazon Cognito returns an InvalidParameterException error. To delete a protected user pool, send a new DeleteUserPool request after you deactivate deletion protection in an UpdateUserPool API request.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.name: deviceConfiguration
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.abstract:
The device-remembering configuration for a user pool. A null value indicates that you have deactivated device remembering in your user pool.

When you provide a value for any DeviceConfiguration field, you activate the Amazon Cognito device-remembering feature.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.name: domain
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.abstract: The domain prefix, if the user pool has a domain associated with it.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.name: emailConfiguration
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.abstract: The email configuration of your user pool. The email configuration type sets your preferred sending method, Amazon Web Services Region, and sender for messages from your user pool.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.name: emailConfigurationFailure
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.abstract: Deprecated. Review error codes from API requests with EventSource:cognito-idp.amazonaws.com in CloudTrail for information about problems with user pool email configuration.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.name: emailVerificationMessage
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.abstract: This parameter is no longer used. See VerificationMessageTemplateType.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.name: emailVerificationSubject
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.abstract: This parameter is no longer used. See VerificationMessageTemplateType.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.name: estimatedNumberOfUsers
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.abstract: A number estimating the size of the user pool.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.name: identifier
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.abstract: The ID of the user pool.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.name: lambdaConfig
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.abstract: The Lambda triggers associated with the user pool.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.name: lastModifiedDate
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.abstract: The date and time, in ISO 8601 format, when the item was modified.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.name: mfaConfiguration
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.abstract:
Can be one of the following values:

  • OFF - MFA tokens aren’t required and can’t be specified during user registration.

  • ON - MFA tokens are required for all user registrations. You can only specify required when you’re initially creating a user pool.

  • OPTIONAL - Users have the option when registering to create an MFA token.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.name: name
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.abstract: The name of the user pool.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.name: policies
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.abstract: The policies associated with the user pool.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.name: schemaAttributes
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.abstract:
A list of the user attributes and their properties in your user pool. The attribute schema contains standard attributes, custom attributes with a custom: prefix, and developer attributes with a dev: prefix. For more information, see User pool attributes.

Developer-only attributes are a legacy feature of user pools, are read-only to all app clients. You can create and update developer-only attributes only with IAM-authenticated API operations. Use app client read/write permissions instead.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.name: smsAuthenticationMessage
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.abstract: The contents of the SMS authentication message.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.name: smsConfiguration
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.abstract: The SMS configuration with the settings that your Amazon Cognito user pool must use to send an SMS message from your Amazon Web Services account through Amazon Simple Notification Service. To send SMS messages with Amazon SNS in the Amazon Web Services Region that you want, the Amazon Cognito user pool uses an Identity and Access Management (IAM) role in your Amazon Web Services account.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.name: smsConfigurationFailure
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.abstract:
The reason why the SMS configuration can’t send the messages to your users.

This message might include comma-separated values to describe why your SMS configuration can’t send messages to user pool end users.

InvalidSmsRoleAccessPolicyException

The Identity and Access Management role that Amazon Cognito uses to send SMS messages isn’t properly configured. For more information, see SmsConfigurationType.

SNSSandbox

The Amazon Web Services account is in the SNS SMS Sandbox and messages will only reach verified end users. This parameter won’t get populated with SNSSandbox if the user creating the user pool doesn’t have SNS permissions. To learn how to move your Amazon Web Services account out of the sandbox, see Moving out of the SMS sandbox.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.name: smsVerificationMessage
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.abstract: This parameter is no longer used. See VerificationMessageTemplateType.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.name: status
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.abstract: This parameter is no longer used.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.name: userAttributeUpdateSettings
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.abstract: The settings for updates to user attributes. These settings include the property AttributesRequireVerificationBeforeUpdate, a user-pool setting that tells Amazon Cognito how to handle changes to the value of your users’ email address and phone number attributes. For more information, see Verifying updates to email addresses and phone numbers.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.name: userPoolAddOns
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.abstract:
User pool add-ons. Contains settings for activation of advanced security features. To log user security information but take no action, set to AUDIT. To configure automatic security responses to risky traffic to your user pool, set to ENFORCED.

For more information, see Adding advanced security to a user pool.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.name: userPoolTags
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.abstract: The tags that are assigned to the user pool. A tag is a label that you can apply to user pools to categorize and manage them in different ways, such as by purpose, owner, environment, or other criteria.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.name: usernameAttributes
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.abstract: Specifies whether a user can use an email address or phone number as a username when they sign up.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.name: usernameConfiguration
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.abstract: Case sensitivity of the username input for the selected sign-in option. For example, when case sensitivity is set to False, users can sign in using either “username” or “Username”. This configuration is immutable once it has been set. For more information, see UsernameConfigurationType.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.name: verificationMessageTemplate
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.abstract: The template for verification messages.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.name: passwordPolicy
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.abstract: The password policy.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.name: creationDate
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.abstract: The date and time, in ISO 8601 format, when the item was created.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.name: identifier
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.abstract: The ID in a user pool description.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.name: lambdaConfig
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.abstract: The Lambda configuration information in a user pool description.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.name: lastModifiedDate
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.abstract: The date and time, in ISO 8601 format, when the item was modified.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.name: name
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.abstract: The name in a user pool description.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.name: status
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.abstract: The user pool status in a user pool description.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.name: accessTokenValidity
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.abstract:
The access token time limit. After this limit expires, your user can’t use their access token. To specify the time unit for AccessTokenValidity as seconds, minutes, hours, or days, set a TokenValidityUnits value in your API request.

For example, when you set AccessTokenValidity to 10 and TokenValidityUnits to hours, your user can authorize access with their access token for 10 hours.

The default time unit for AccessTokenValidity in an API request is hours. Valid range is displayed below in seconds.

If you don’t specify otherwise in the configuration of your app client, your access tokens are valid for one hour.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.name: allowedOAuthFlows
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.abstract:
The allowed OAuth flows.

code

Use a code grant flow, which provides an authorization code as the response. This code can be exchanged for access tokens with the /oauth2/token endpoint.

implicit

Issue the access token (and, optionally, ID token, based on scopes) directly to your user.

client_credentials

Issue the access token from the /oauth2/token endpoint directly to a non-person user using a combination of the client ID and client secret.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.name: allowedOAuthFlowsUserPoolClient
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.abstract:
Set to true to use OAuth 2.0 features in your user pool app client.

AllowedOAuthFlowsUserPoolClient must be true before you can configure the following features in your app client.

  • CallBackURLs: Callback URLs.

  • LogoutURLs: Sign-out redirect URLs.

  • AllowedOAuthScopes: OAuth 2.0 scopes.

  • AllowedOAuthFlows: Support for authorization code, implicit, and client credentials OAuth 2.0 grants.

To use OAuth 2.0 features, configure one of these features in the Amazon Cognito console or set AllowedOAuthFlowsUserPoolClient to true in a CreateUserPoolClient or UpdateUserPoolClient API request. If you don’t set a value for AllowedOAuthFlowsUserPoolClient in a request with the CLI or SDKs, it defaults to false.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.name: allowedOAuthScopes
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.abstract: The OAuth scopes that your app client supports. Possible values that OAuth provides are phone, email, openid, and profile. Possible values that Amazon Web Services provides are aws.cognito.signin.user.admin. Amazon Cognito also supports custom scopes that you create in Resource Servers.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.name: analyticsConfiguration
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.abstract:
The Amazon Pinpoint analytics configuration for the user pool client.

Amazon Cognito user pools only support sending events to Amazon Pinpoint projects in the US East (N. Virginia) us-east-1 Region, regardless of the Region where the user pool resides.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.name: authSessionValidity
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.abstract: Amazon Cognito creates a session token for each API request in an authentication flow. AuthSessionValidity is the duration, in minutes, of that session token. Your user pool native user must respond to each authentication challenge before the session expires.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.name: callbackURLs
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.abstract:
A list of allowed redirect (callback) URLs for the IdPs.

A redirect URI must:

  • Be an absolute URI.

  • Be registered with the authorization server.

  • Not include a fragment component.

See OAuth 2.0 - Redirection Endpoint.

Amazon Cognito requires HTTPS over HTTP except for http://localhost for testing purposes only.

App callback URLs such as myapp://example are also supported.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.name: clientId
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.abstract: The ID of the client associated with the user pool.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.name: clientName
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.abstract: The client name from the user pool request of the client type.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.name: clientSecret
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.abstract: The client secret from the user pool request of the client type.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.name: creationDate
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.abstract: The date and time, in ISO 8601 format, when the item was created.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.name: defaultRedirectURI
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.abstract:
The default redirect URI. Must be in the CallbackURLs list.

A redirect URI must:

  • Be an absolute URI.

  • Be registered with the authorization server.

  • Not include a fragment component.

See OAuth 2.0 - Redirection Endpoint.

Amazon Cognito requires HTTPS over HTTP except for http://localhost for testing purposes only.

App callback URLs such as myapp://example are also supported.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.name: enablePropagateAdditionalUserContextData
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.abstract:
When EnablePropagateAdditionalUserContextData is true, Amazon Cognito accepts an IpAddress value that you send in the UserContextData parameter. The UserContextData parameter sends information to Amazon Cognito advanced security for risk analysis. You can send UserContextData when you sign in Amazon Cognito native users with the InitiateAuth and RespondToAuthChallenge API operations.

When EnablePropagateAdditionalUserContextData is false, you can’t send your user’s source IP address to Amazon Cognito advanced security with unauthenticated API operations. EnablePropagateAdditionalUserContextData doesn’t affect whether you can send a source IP address in a ContextData parameter with the authenticated API operations AdminInitiateAuth and AdminRespondToAuthChallenge.

You can only activate EnablePropagateAdditionalUserContextData in an app client that has a client secret. For more information about propagation of user context data, see Adding user device and session data to API requests.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.name: enableTokenRevocation
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.abstract: Indicates whether token revocation is activated for the user pool client. When you create a new user pool client, token revocation is activated by default. For more information about revoking tokens, see RevokeToken.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.name: explicitAuthFlows
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.abstract:
The authentication flows that you want your user pool client to support. For each app client in your user pool, you can sign in your users with any combination of one or more flows, including with a user name and Secure Remote Password (SRP), a user name and password, or a custom authentication process that you define with Lambda functions.

If you don’t specify a value for ExplicitAuthFlows, your user client supports ALLOW_REFRESH_TOKEN_AUTH, ALLOW_USER_SRP_AUTH, and ALLOW_CUSTOM_AUTH.

Valid values include:

  • ALLOW_ADMIN_USER_PASSWORD_AUTH: Enable admin based user password authentication flow ADMIN_USER_PASSWORD_AUTH. This setting replaces the ADMIN_NO_SRP_AUTH setting. With this authentication flow, your app passes a user name and password to Amazon Cognito in the request, instead of using the Secure Remote Password (SRP) protocol to securely transmit the password.

  • ALLOW_CUSTOM_AUTH: Enable Lambda trigger based authentication.

  • ALLOW_USER_PASSWORD_AUTH: Enable user password-based authentication. In this flow, Amazon Cognito receives the password in the request instead of using the SRP protocol to verify passwords.

  • ALLOW_USER_SRP_AUTH: Enable SRP-based authentication.

  • ALLOW_REFRESH_TOKEN_AUTH: Enable authflow to refresh tokens.

In some environments, you will see the values ADMIN_NO_SRP_AUTH, CUSTOM_AUTH_FLOW_ONLY, or USER_PASSWORD_AUTH. You can’t assign these legacy ExplicitAuthFlows values to user pool clients at the same time as values that begin with ALLOW_, like ALLOW_USER_SRP_AUTH.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.name: idTokenValidity
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.abstract:
The ID token time limit. After this limit expires, your user can’t use their ID token. To specify the time unit for IdTokenValidity as seconds, minutes, hours, or days, set a TokenValidityUnits value in your API request.

For example, when you set IdTokenValidity as 10 and TokenValidityUnits as hours, your user can authenticate their session with their ID token for 10 hours.

The default time unit for IdTokenValidity in an API request is hours. Valid range is displayed below in seconds.

If you don’t specify otherwise in the configuration of your app client, your ID tokens are valid for one hour.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.name: lastModifiedDate
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.abstract: The date and time, in ISO 8601 format, when the item was modified.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.name: logoutURLs
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.abstract: A list of allowed logout URLs for the IdPs.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.name: preventUserExistenceErrors
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.abstract:
Errors and responses that you want Amazon Cognito APIs to return during authentication, account confirmation, and password recovery when the user doesn’t exist in the user pool. When set to ENABLED and the user doesn’t exist, authentication returns an error indicating either the username or password was incorrect. Account confirmation and password recovery return a response indicating a code was sent to a simulated destination. When set to LEGACY, those APIs return a UserNotFoundException exception if the user doesn’t exist in the user pool.

Valid values include:

  • ENABLED - This prevents user existence-related errors.

  • LEGACY - This represents the old behavior of Amazon Cognito where user existence related errors aren’t prevented.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.name: readAttributes
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.abstract:
The list of user attributes that you want your app client to have read-only access to. After your user authenticates in your app, their access token authorizes them to read their own attribute value for any attribute in this list. An example of this kind of activity is when your user selects a link to view their profile information. Your app makes a GetUser API request to retrieve and display your user’s profile data.

When you don’t specify the ReadAttributes for your app client, your app can read the values of email_verified, phone_number_verified, and the Standard attributes of your user pool. When your user pool has read access to these default attributes, ReadAttributes doesn’t return any information. Amazon Cognito only populates ReadAttributes in the API response if you have specified your own custom set of read attributes.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.name: refreshTokenValidity
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.abstract:
The refresh token time limit. After this limit expires, your user can’t use their refresh token. To specify the time unit for RefreshTokenValidity as seconds, minutes, hours, or days, set a TokenValidityUnits value in your API request.

For example, when you set RefreshTokenValidity as 10 and TokenValidityUnits as days, your user can refresh their session and retrieve new access and ID tokens for 10 days.

The default time unit for RefreshTokenValidity in an API request is days. You can’t set RefreshTokenValidity to 0. If you do, Amazon Cognito overrides the value with the default value of 30 days. Valid range is displayed below in seconds.

If you don’t specify otherwise in the configuration of your app client, your refresh tokens are valid for 30 days.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.name: supportedIdentityProviders
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.abstract: A list of provider names for the IdPs that this client supports. The following are supported: COGNITO, Facebook, Google, SignInWithApple, LoginWithAmazon, and the names of your own SAML and OIDC providers.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.name: tokenValidityUnits
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.abstract: The time units used to specify the token validity times of each token type: ID, access, and refresh.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.name: userPoolId
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.abstract: The user pool ID for the user pool client.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.name: writeAttributes
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.abstract:
The list of user attributes that you want your app client to have write access to. After your user authenticates in your app, their access token authorizes them to set or modify their own attribute value for any attribute in this list. An example of this kind of activity is when you present your user with a form to update their profile information and they change their last name. Your app then makes an UpdateUserAttributes API request and sets family_name to the new value.

When you don’t specify the WriteAttributes for your app client, your app can write the values of the Standard attributes of your user pool. When your user pool has write access to these default attributes, WriteAttributes doesn’t return any information. Amazon Cognito only populates WriteAttributes in the API response if you have specified your own custom set of write attributes.

If your app client allows users to sign in through an IdP, this array must include all attributes that you have mapped to IdP attributes. Amazon Cognito updates mapped attributes when users sign in to your application through an IdP. If your app client does not have write access to a mapped attribute, Amazon Cognito throws an error when it tries to update the attribute. For more information, see Specifying IdP Attribute Mappings for Your user pool.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.name: clientId
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.abstract: The ID of the client associated with the user pool.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.name: clientName
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.abstract: The client name from the user pool client description.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.name: userPoolId
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.abstract: The user pool ID for the user pool where you want to describe the user pool client.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.name: advancedSecurityMode
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserPo.abstract: The operating mode of advanced security features in your user pool.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserIm.name: cloudWatchLogsRoleArn
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserIm.abstract: The role Amazon Resource Name (ARN) for the Amazon CloudWatch Logging role for the user import job. For more information, see “Creating the CloudWatch Logs IAM Role” in the Amazon Cognito Developer Guide.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserIm.name: completionDate
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserIm.abstract: The date when the user import job was completed.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserIm.name: completionMessage
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserIm.abstract: The message returned when the user import job is completed.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserIm.name: creationDate
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserIm.abstract: The date and time, in ISO 8601 format, when the item was created.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserIm.name: failedUsers
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserIm.abstract: The number of users that couldn’t be imported.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserIm.name: importedUsers
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserIm.abstract: The number of users that were successfully imported.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserIm.name: jobId
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserIm.abstract: The job ID for the user import job.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserIm.name: jobName
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserIm.abstract: The job name for the user import job.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserIm.name: preSignedUrl
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserIm.abstract: The pre-signed URL to be used to upload the .csv file.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserIm.name: skippedUsers
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserIm.abstract: The number of users that were skipped.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserIm.name: startDate
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserIm.abstract: The date when the user import job was started.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserIm.name: status
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserIm.abstract:
The status of the user import job. One of the following:

  • Created - The job was created but not started.

  • Pending - A transition state. You have started the job, but it has not begun importing users yet.

  • InProgress - The job has started, and users are being imported.

  • Stopping - You have stopped the job, but the job has not stopped importing users yet.

  • Stopped - You have stopped the job, and the job has stopped importing users.

  • Succeeded - The job has completed successfully.

  • Failed - The job has stopped due to an error.

  • Expired - You created a job, but did not start the job within 24-48 hours. All data associated with the job was deleted, and the job can’t be started.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserIm.name: userPoolId
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserIm.abstract: The user pool ID for the user pool that the users are being imported into.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserCo.name: encodedData
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserCo.abstract: Encoded device-fingerprint details that your app collected with the Amazon Cognito context data collection library. For more information, see Adding user device and session data to API requests.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserCo.name: ipAddress
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserCo.abstract: The source IP address of your user’s device.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserAt.name: attributesRequireVerificationBeforeUpdate
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUserAt.abstract:
Requires that your user verifies their email address, phone number, or both before Amazon Cognito updates the value of that attribute. When you update a user attribute that has this option activated, Amazon Cognito sends a verification message to the new phone number or email address. Amazon Cognito doesn’t change the value of the attribute until your user responds to the verification message and confirms the new value.

You can verify an updated email address or phone number with a VerifyUserAttribute API request. You can also call the AdminUpdateUserAttributes API and set email_verified or phone_number_verified to true.

When AttributesRequireVerificationBeforeUpdate is false, your user pool doesn’t require that your users verify attribute changes before Amazon Cognito updates them. In a user pool where AttributesRequireVerificationBeforeUpdate is false, API operations that change attribute values can immediately update a user’s email or phone_number attribute.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUpdate.name: accountRecoverySetting
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUpdate.abstract: The available verified method a user can use to recover their password when they call ForgotPassword. You can use this setting to define a preferred method when a user has more than one method available. With this setting, SMS doesn’t qualify for a valid password recovery mechanism if the user also has SMS multi-factor authentication (MFA) activated. In the absence of this setting, Amazon Cognito uses the legacy behavior to determine the recovery method where SMS is preferred through email.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUpdate.name: adminCreateUserConfig
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUpdate.abstract: The configuration for AdminCreateUser requests.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUpdate.name: autoVerifiedAttributes
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUpdate.abstract: The attributes that are automatically verified when Amazon Cognito requests to update user pools.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUpdate.name: deletionProtection
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUpdate.abstract:
When active, DeletionProtection prevents accidental deletion of your user pool. Before you can delete a user pool that you have protected against deletion, you must deactivate this feature.

When you try to delete a protected user pool in a DeleteUserPool API request, Amazon Cognito returns an InvalidParameterException error. To delete a protected user pool, send a new DeleteUserPool request after you deactivate deletion protection in an UpdateUserPool API request.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUpdate.name: deviceConfiguration
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUpdate.abstract:
The device-remembering configuration for a user pool. A null value indicates that you have deactivated device remembering in your user pool.

When you provide a value for any DeviceConfiguration field, you activate the Amazon Cognito device-remembering feature.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUpdate.name: emailConfiguration
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUpdate.abstract: The email configuration of your user pool. The email configuration type sets your preferred sending method, Amazon Web Services Region, and sender for email invitation and verification messages from your user pool.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUpdate.name: emailVerificationMessage
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUpdate.abstract: This parameter is no longer used. See VerificationMessageTemplateType.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUpdate.name: emailVerificationSubject
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUpdate.abstract: This parameter is no longer used. See VerificationMessageTemplateType.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUpdate.name: lambdaConfig
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUpdate.abstract: The Lambda configuration information from the request to update the user pool.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUpdate.name: mfaConfiguration
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUpdate.abstract:
Possible values include:

  • OFF - MFA tokens aren’t required and can’t be specified during user registration.

  • ON - MFA tokens are required for all user registrations. You can only specify ON when you’re initially creating a user pool. You can use the SetUserPoolMfaConfig API operation to turn MFA “ON” for existing user pools.

  • OPTIONAL - Users have the option when registering to create an MFA token.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUpdate.name: policies
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUpdate.abstract: A container with the policies you want to update in a user pool.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUpdate.name: smsAuthenticationMessage
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUpdate.abstract: The contents of the SMS authentication message.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUpdate.name: smsConfiguration
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUpdate.abstract: The SMS configuration with the settings that your Amazon Cognito user pool must use to send an SMS message from your Amazon Web Services account through Amazon Simple Notification Service. To send SMS messages with Amazon SNS in the Amazon Web Services Region that you want, the Amazon Cognito user pool uses an Identity and Access Management (IAM) role in your Amazon Web Services account.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUpdate.name: smsVerificationMessage
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUpdate.abstract: This parameter is no longer used. See VerificationMessageTemplateType.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUpdate.name: userAttributeUpdateSettings
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUpdate.abstract: The settings for updates to user attributes. These settings include the property AttributesRequireVerificationBeforeUpdate, a user-pool setting that tells Amazon Cognito how to handle changes to the value of your users’ email address and phone number attributes. For more information, see Verifying updates to email addresses and phone numbers.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUpdate.name: userPoolAddOns
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUpdate.abstract:
User pool add-ons. Contains settings for activation of advanced security features. To log user security information but take no action, set to AUDIT. To configure automatic security responses to risky traffic to your user pool, set to ENFORCED.

For more information, see Adding advanced security to a user pool.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUpdate.name: userPoolId
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUpdate.abstract: The user pool ID for the user pool you want to update.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUpdate.name: userPoolTags
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUpdate.abstract: The tag keys and values to assign to the user pool. A tag is a label that you can use to categorize and manage user pools in different ways, such as by purpose, owner, environment, or other criteria.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUpdate.name: verificationMessageTemplate
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUpdate.abstract: The template for verification messages.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUpdate.name: cloudFrontDomain
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUpdate.abstract: The Amazon CloudFront endpoint that Amazon Cognito set up when you added the custom domain to your user pool.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUpdate.name: customDomainConfig
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUpdate.abstract: The configuration for a custom domain that hosts the sign-up and sign-in pages for your application. Use this object to specify an SSL certificate that is managed by ACM.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUpdate.name: domain
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUpdate.abstract:
The domain name for the custom domain that hosts the sign-up and sign-in pages for your application. One example might be auth.example.com.

This string can include only lowercase letters, numbers, and hyphens. Don’t use a hyphen for the first or last character. Use periods to separate subdomain names.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUpdate.name: userPoolId
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUpdate.abstract: The ID of the user pool that is associated with the custom domain whose certificate you’re updating.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUpdate.name: userPoolClient
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUpdate.abstract: The user pool client value from the response from the server when you request to update the user pool client.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUpdate.name: accessTokenValidity
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUpdate.abstract:
The access token time limit. After this limit expires, your user can’t use their access token. To specify the time unit for AccessTokenValidity as seconds, minutes, hours, or days, set a TokenValidityUnits value in your API request.

For example, when you set AccessTokenValidity to 10 and TokenValidityUnits to hours, your user can authorize access with their access token for 10 hours.

The default time unit for AccessTokenValidity in an API request is hours. Valid range is displayed below in seconds.

If you don’t specify otherwise in the configuration of your app client, your access tokens are valid for one hour.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUpdate.name: allowedOAuthFlows
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUpdate.abstract:
The allowed OAuth flows.

code

Use a code grant flow, which provides an authorization code as the response. This code can be exchanged for access tokens with the /oauth2/token endpoint.

implicit

Issue the access token (and, optionally, ID token, based on scopes) directly to your user.

client_credentials

Issue the access token from the /oauth2/token endpoint directly to a non-person user using a combination of the client ID and client secret.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUpdate.name: allowedOAuthFlowsUserPoolClient
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUpdate.abstract:
Set to true to use OAuth 2.0 features in your user pool app client.

AllowedOAuthFlowsUserPoolClient must be true before you can configure the following features in your app client.

  • CallBackURLs: Callback URLs.

  • LogoutURLs: Sign-out redirect URLs.

  • AllowedOAuthScopes: OAuth 2.0 scopes.

  • AllowedOAuthFlows: Support for authorization code, implicit, and client credentials OAuth 2.0 grants.

To use OAuth 2.0 features, configure one of these features in the Amazon Cognito console or set AllowedOAuthFlowsUserPoolClient to true in a CreateUserPoolClient or UpdateUserPoolClient API request. If you don’t set a value for AllowedOAuthFlowsUserPoolClient in a request with the CLI or SDKs, it defaults to false.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUpdate.name: allowedOAuthScopes
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUpdate.abstract: The allowed OAuth scopes. Possible values provided by OAuth are phone, email, openid, and profile. Possible values provided by Amazon Web Services are aws.cognito.signin.user.admin. Custom scopes created in Resource Servers are also supported.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUpdate.name: analyticsConfiguration
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUpdate.abstract:
The Amazon Pinpoint analytics configuration necessary to collect metrics for this user pool.

In Amazon Web Services Regions where Amazon Pinpoint isn’t available, user pools only support sending events to Amazon Pinpoint projects in us-east-1. In Regions where Amazon Pinpoint is available, user pools support sending events to Amazon Pinpoint projects within that same Region.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUpdate.name: authSessionValidity
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUpdate.abstract: Amazon Cognito creates a session token for each API request in an authentication flow. AuthSessionValidity is the duration, in minutes, of that session token. Your user pool native user must respond to each authentication challenge before the session expires.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUpdate.name: callbackURLs
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUpdate.abstract:
A list of allowed redirect (callback) URLs for the IdPs.

A redirect URI must:

  • Be an absolute URI.

  • Be registered with the authorization server.

  • Not include a fragment component.

See OAuth 2.0 - Redirection Endpoint.

Amazon Cognito requires HTTPS over HTTP except for http://localhost for testing purposes only.

App callback URLs such as myapp://example are also supported.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUpdate.name: clientId
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUpdate.abstract: The ID of the client associated with the user pool.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUpdate.name: clientName
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUpdate.abstract: The client name from the update user pool client request.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUpdate.name: defaultRedirectURI
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUpdate.abstract:
The default redirect URI. Must be in the CallbackURLs list.

A redirect URI must:

  • Be an absolute URI.

  • Be registered with the authorization server.

  • Not include a fragment component.

See OAuth 2.0 - Redirection Endpoint.

Amazon Cognito requires HTTPS over HTTP except for http://localhost for testing purposes only.

App callback URLs such as myapp://example are also supported.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUpdate.name: enablePropagateAdditionalUserContextData
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUpdate.abstract: Activates the propagation of additional user context data. For more information about propagation of user context data, see Adding advanced security to a user pool. If you don’t include this parameter, you can’t send device fingerprint information, including source IP address, to Amazon Cognito advanced security. You can only activate EnablePropagateAdditionalUserContextData in an app client that has a client secret.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUpdate.name: enableTokenRevocation
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUpdate.abstract: Activates or deactivates token revocation. For more information about revoking tokens, see RevokeToken.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUpdate.name: explicitAuthFlows
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUpdate.abstract:

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUpdate.name: supportedIdentityProviders
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUpdate.abstract: A list of provider names for the IdPs that this client supports. The following are supported: COGNITO, Facebook, Google, SignInWithApple, LoginWithAmazon, and the names of your own SAML and OIDC providers.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUpdate.name: tokenValidityUnits
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUpdate.abstract: The time units you use when you set the duration of ID, access, and refresh tokens. The default unit for RefreshToken is days, and the default for ID and access tokens is hours.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUpdate.name: userPoolId
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUpdate.abstract: The user pool ID for the user pool where you want to update the user pool client.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUpdate.name: writeAttributes
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUpdate.abstract:
The list of user attributes that you want your app client to have write access to. After your user authenticates in your app, their access token authorizes them to set or modify their own attribute value for any attribute in this list. Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUpdate.name: codeDeliveryDetailsList
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUpdate.abstract: The code delivery details list from the server for the request to update user attributes.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUpdate.name: accessToken
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUpdate.abstract: A valid access token that Amazon Cognito issued to the user whose user attributes you want to update.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUpdate.name: clientMetadata
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUpdate.abstract:
A map of custom key-value pairs that you can provide as input for any custom workflows that this action initiates.

You create custom workflows by assigning Lambda functions to user pool triggers. When you use the UpdateUserAttributes API action, Amazon Cognito invokes the function that is assigned to the custom message trigger. When Amazon Cognito invokes this function, it passes a JSON payload, which the function receives as input. This payload contains a clientMetadata attribute, which provides the data that you assigned to the ClientMetadata parameter in your UpdateUserAttributes request. In your function code in Lambda, you can process the clientMetadata value to enhance your workflow for your specific needs.

For more information, see Customizing user pool Workflows with Lambda Triggers in the Amazon Cognito Developer Guide.

When you use the ClientMetadata parameter, remember that Amazon Cognito won’t do the following:

  • Store the ClientMetadata value. This data is available only to Lambda triggers that are assigned to a user pool to support custom workflows. If your user pool configuration doesn’t include triggers, the ClientMetadata parameter serves no purpose.

  • Validate the ClientMetadata value.

  • Encrypt the ClientMetadata value. Don’t use Amazon Cognito to provide sensitive information.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUpdate.name: userAttributes
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUpdate.abstract:
An array of name-value pairs representing user attributes.

For custom attributes, you must prepend the custom: prefix to the attribute name.

If you have set an attribute to require verification before Amazon Cognito updates its value, this request doesn’t immediately update the value of that attribute. After your user receives and responds to a verification message to verify the new value, Amazon Cognito updates the attribute value. Your user can sign in and receive messages with the original attribute value until they verify the new value.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUpdate.name: precedence

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUpdate.name: roleArn
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUpdate.abstract: The new role Amazon Resource Name (ARN) for the group. This is used for setting the cognito:roles and cognito:preferred_role claims in the token.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUpdate.name: userPoolId
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUpdate.abstract: The user pool ID for the user pool.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUpdate.name: accessToken
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUpdate.abstract: A valid access token that Amazon Cognito issued to the user whose device status you want to update.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUpdate.name: deviceKey
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUpdate.abstract: The device key.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUpdate.name: deviceRememberedStatus
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUpdate.abstract: The status of whether a device is remembered.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUpdate.name: eventId
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUpdate.abstract: The event ID.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUpdate.name: feedbackToken
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUpdate.abstract: The feedback token.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUpdate.name: feedbackValue
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUpdate.abstract: The authentication event feedback value. When you provide a FeedbackValue value of valid, you tell Amazon Cognito that you trust a user session where Amazon Cognito has evaluated some level of risk. When you provide a FeedbackValue value of invalid, you tell Amazon Cognito that you don’t trust a user session, or you don’t believe that Amazon Cognito evaluated a high-enough risk level.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUpdate.name: userPoolId
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUpdate.abstract: The user pool ID.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUpdate.name: username
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUpdate.abstract: The username of the user that you want to query or modify. The value of this parameter is typically your user’s username, but it can be any of their alias attributes. If username isn’t an alias attribute in your user pool, you can also use their sub in this request.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUntagR.name: resourceArn
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUntagR.abstract: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the user pool that the tags are assigned to.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUntagR.name: tagKeys
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUntagR.abstract: The keys of the tags to remove from the user pool.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUICust.name: CSS
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUICust.abstract: The CSS values in the UI customization.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUICust.name: clientId
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUICust.abstract: The client ID for the client app.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUICust.name: creationDate

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUICust.name: imageUrl

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUICust.name: lastModifiedDate

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUICust.name: userPoolId
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderUICust.abstract: The user pool ID for the user pool.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderTokenV.name: accessToken
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderTokenV.abstract: A time unit of seconds, minutes, hours, or days for the value that you set in the AccessTokenValidity parameter. The default AccessTokenValidity time unit is hours. AccessTokenValidity duration can range from five minutes to one day.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderTokenV.name: idToken
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderTokenV.abstract: A time unit of seconds, minutes, hours, or days for the value that you set in the IdTokenValidity parameter. The default IdTokenValidity time unit is hours. IdTokenValidity duration can range from five minutes to one day.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderTokenV.name: refreshToken
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderTokenV.abstract: A time unit of seconds, minutes, hours, or days for the value that you set in the RefreshTokenValidity parameter. The default RefreshTokenValidity time unit is days. RefreshTokenValidity duration can range from 60 minutes to 10 years.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderTagRes.name: resourceArn

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderStopUs.name: userImportJob

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderStartU.name: userImportJob

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderStartU.name: jobId

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderStartU.name: userPoolId

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderSoftwa.name: enabled
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderSoftwa.abstract: Specifies whether software token MFA is activated. If an MFA type is activated for a user, the user will be prompted for MFA during all sign-in attempts, unless device tracking is turned on and the device has been trusted.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderSoftwa.name: preferredMfa
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderSoftwa.abstract: Specifies whether software token MFA is the preferred MFA method.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderSoftwa.name: enabled
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderSoftwa.abstract: Specifies whether software token MFA is activated.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderSmsMfa.name: smsAuthenticationMessage
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderSmsMfa.abstract: The SMS authentication message that will be sent to users with the code they must sign in. The message must contain the ‘{####}’ placeholder, which is replaced with the code. If the message isn’t included, and default message will be used.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderSmsMfa.name: smsConfiguration
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderSmsMfa.abstract: The SMS configuration with the settings that your Amazon Cognito user pool must use to send an SMS message from your Amazon Web Services account through Amazon Simple Notification Service. To request Amazon SNS in the Amazon Web Services Region that you want, the Amazon Cognito user pool uses an Identity and Access Management (IAM) role that you provide for your Amazon Web Services account.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderSmsCon.name: externalId
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderSmsCon.abstract:
The external ID provides additional security for your IAM role. You can use an ExternalId with the IAM role that you use with Amazon SNS to send SMS messages for your user pool. If you provide an ExternalId, your Amazon Cognito user pool includes it in the request to assume your IAM role. You can configure the role trust policy to require that Amazon Cognito, and any principal, provide the ExternalID. If you use the Amazon Cognito Management Console to create a role for SMS multi-factor authentication (MFA), Amazon Cognito creates a role with the required permissions and a trust policy that demonstrates use of the ExternalId.

For more information about the ExternalId of a role, see How to use an external ID when granting access to your Amazon Web Services resources to a third party

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderSmsCon.name: snsCallerArn
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderSmsCon.abstract: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the Amazon SNS caller. This is the ARN of the IAM role in your Amazon Web Services account that Amazon Cognito will use to send SMS messages. SMS messages are subject to a spending limit.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderSmsCon.name: snsRegion
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderSmsCon.abstract:
The Amazon Web Services Region to use with Amazon SNS integration. You can choose the same Region as your user pool, or a supported Legacy Amazon SNS alternate Region.

Amazon Cognito resources in the Asia Pacific (Seoul) Amazon Web Services Region must use your Amazon SNS configuration in the Asia Pacific (Tokyo) Region. For more information, see SMS message settings for Amazon Cognito user pools.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderSignUp.name: codeDeliveryDetails
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderSignUp.abstract: The code delivery details returned by the server response to the user registration request.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderSignUp.name: userConfirmed
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderSignUp.abstract: A response from the server indicating that a user registration has been confirmed.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderSignUp.name: userSub
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderSignUp.abstract: The UUID of the authenticated user. This isn’t the same as username.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderSignUp.name: analyticsMetadata
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderSignUp.abstract: The Amazon Pinpoint analytics metadata that contributes to your metrics for SignUp calls.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderSignUp.name: clientId
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderSignUp.abstract: The ID of the client associated with the user pool.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderSignUp.name: clientMetadata
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderSignUp.abstract:
A map of custom key-value pairs that you can provide as input for any custom workflows that this action triggers.

You create custom workflows by assigning Lambda functions to user pool triggers. When you use the SignUp API action, Amazon Cognito invokes any functions that are assigned to the following triggers: pre sign-up, custom message, and post confirmation. When Amazon Cognito invokes any of these functions, it passes a JSON payload, which the function receives as input. This payload contains a clientMetadata attribute, which provides the data that you assigned to the ClientMetadata parameter in your SignUp request. In your function code in Lambda, you can process the clientMetadata value to enhance your workflow for your specific needs.

For more information, see Customizing user pool Workflows with Lambda Triggers in the Amazon Cognito Developer Guide.

When you use the ClientMetadata parameter, remember that Amazon Cognito won’t do the following:

  • Store the ClientMetadata value. This data is available only to Lambda triggers that are assigned to a user pool to support custom workflows. If your user pool configuration doesn’t include triggers, the ClientMetadata parameter serves no purpose.

  • Validate the ClientMetadata value.

  • Encrypt the ClientMetadata value. Don’t use Amazon Cognito to provide sensitive information.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderSignUp.name: password
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderSignUp.abstract: The password of the user you want to register.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderSignUp.name: secretHash
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderSignUp.abstract: A keyed-hash message authentication code (HMAC) calculated using the secret key of a user pool client and username plus the client ID in the message.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderSignUp.name: userAttributes
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderSignUp.abstract:
An array of name-value pairs representing user attributes.

For custom attributes, you must prepend the custom: prefix to the attribute name.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderSignUp.name: userContextData
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderSignUp.abstract: Contextual data about your user session, such as the device fingerprint, IP address, or location. Amazon Cognito advanced security evaluates the risk of an authentication event based on the context that your app generates and passes to Amazon Cognito when it makes API requests.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderSignUp.name: username
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderSignUp.abstract: The username of the user that you want to sign up. The value of this parameter is typically a username, but can be any alias attribute in your user pool.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderSignUp.name: validationData
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderSignUp.abstract:
Temporary user attributes that contribute to the outcomes of your pre sign-up Lambda trigger. This set of key-value pairs are for custom validation of information that you collect from your users but don’t need to retain.

Your Lambda function can analyze this additional data and act on it. Your function might perform external API operations like logging user attributes and validation data to Amazon CloudWatch Logs. Validation data might also affect the response that your function returns to Amazon Cognito, like automatically confirming the user if they sign up from within your network.

For more information about the pre sign-up Lambda trigger, see Pre sign-up Lambda trigger.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderSetUse.name: accessToken
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderSetUse.abstract: A valid access token that Amazon Cognito issued to the user whose user settings you want to configure.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderSetUse.name: MFAOptions
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderSetUse.abstract: You can use this parameter only to set an SMS configuration that uses SMS for delivery.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderSetUse.name: mfaConfiguration
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderSetUse.abstract:
The MFA configuration. Valid values include:

  • OFF MFA won’t be used for any users.

  • ON MFA is required for all users to sign in.

  • OPTIONAL MFA will be required only for individual users who have an MFA factor enabled.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderSetUse.name: mfaConfiguration
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderSetUse.abstract:
The MFA configuration. If you set the MfaConfiguration value to ‘ON’, only users who have set up an MFA factor can sign in. To learn more, see Adding Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) to a user pool. Valid values include:

  • OFF MFA won’t be used for any users.

  • ON MFA is required for all users to sign in.

  • OPTIONAL MFA will be required only for individual users who have an MFA factor activated.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderSetUse.name: accessToken
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderSetUse.abstract: A valid access token that Amazon Cognito issued to the user whose MFA preference you want to set.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderSetUse.name: SMSMfaSettings
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderSetUse.abstract: The SMS text message multi-factor authentication (MFA) settings.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderSetUse.name: softwareTokenMfaSettings
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderSetUse.abstract: The time-based one-time password (TOTP) software token MFA settings.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderSetUIC.name: CSS
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderSetUIC.abstract: The CSS values in the UI customization.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderSetUIC.name: clientId
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderSetUIC.abstract: The client ID for the client app.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderSetUIC.name: imageFile
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderSetUIC.abstract: The uploaded logo image for the UI customization.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderSetUIC.name: userPoolId
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderSetUIC.abstract: The user pool ID for the user pool.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderSetRis.name: clientId
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderSetRis.abstract:
The app client ID. If ClientId is null, then the risk configuration is mapped to userPoolId. When the client ID is null, the same risk configuration is applied to all the clients in the userPool.

Otherwise, ClientId is mapped to the client. When the client ID isn’t null, the user pool configuration is overridden and the risk configuration for the client is used instead.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderSetRis.name: riskExceptionConfiguration
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderSetRis.abstract: The configuration to override the risk decision.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderSetLog.name: logDeliveryConfiguration
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderSetLog.abstract: The detailed activity logging configuration that you applied to the requested user pool.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderSetLog.name: logConfigurations
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderSetLog.abstract: A collection of all of the detailed activity logging configurations for a user pool.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderSetLog.name: userPoolId
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderSetLog.abstract: The ID of the user pool where you want to configure detailed activity logging .

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderSchema.name: attributeDataType
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderSchema.abstract: The data format of the values for your attribute. When you choose an AttributeDataType, Amazon Cognito validates the input against the data type. A custom attribute value in your user’s ID token is always a string, for example "custom:isMember" : "true" or "custom:YearsAsMember" : "12".

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderSchema.name: developerOnlyAttribute
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderSchema.abstract:
You should use WriteAttributes in the user pool client to control how attributes can be mutated for new use cases instead of using DeveloperOnlyAttribute.

Specifies whether the attribute type is developer only. This attribute can only be modified by an administrator. Users won’t be able to modify this attribute using their access token. For example, DeveloperOnlyAttribute can be modified using AdminUpdateUserAttributes but can’t be updated using UpdateUserAttributes.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderSchema.name: varying
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderSchema.abstract:
Specifies whether the value of the attribute can be changed.

Any user pool attribute whose value you map from an IdP attribute must be mutable, with a parameter value of true. Amazon Cognito updates mapped attributes when users sign in to your application through an IdP. If an attribute is immutable, Amazon Cognito throws an error when it attempts to update the attribute. For more information, see Specifying Identity Provider Attribute Mappings for Your User Pool.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderSchema.name: name
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderSchema.abstract: The name of your user pool attribute. When you create or update a user pool, adding a schema attribute creates a custom or developer-only attribute. When you add an attribute with a Name value of MyAttribute, Amazon Cognito creates the custom attribute custom:MyAttribute. When DeveloperOnlyAttribute is true, Amazon Cognito creates your attribute as dev:MyAttribute. In an operation that describes a user pool, Amazon Cognito returns this value as value for standard attributes, custom:value for custom attributes, and dev:value for developer-only attributes..

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderSchema.name: numberAttributeConstraints
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderSchema.abstract: Specifies the constraints for an attribute of the number type.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderSchema.name: required
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderSchema.abstract: Specifies whether a user pool attribute is required. If the attribute is required and the user doesn’t provide a value, registration or sign-in will fail.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderSchema.name: stringAttributeConstraints
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderSchema.abstract: Specifies the constraints for an attribute of the string type.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderSMSMfa.name: enabled
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderSMSMfa.abstract: Specifies whether SMS text message MFA is activated. If an MFA type is activated for a user, the user will be prompted for MFA during all sign-in attempts, unless device tracking is turned on and the device has been trusted.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderSMSMfa.name: preferredMfa
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderSMSMfa.abstract: Specifies whether SMS is the preferred MFA method.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderRiskEx.name: blockedIPRangeList
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderRiskEx.abstract: Overrides the risk decision to always block the pre-authentication requests. The IP range is in CIDR notation, a compact representation of an IP address and its routing prefix.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderRiskEx.name: skippedIPRangeList
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderRiskEx.abstract: Risk detection isn’t performed on the IP addresses in this range list. The IP range is in CIDR notation.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderRiskCo.name: accountTakeoverRiskConfiguration
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderRiskCo.abstract: The account takeover risk configuration object, including the NotifyConfiguration object and Actions to take if there is an account takeover.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderRiskCo.name: compromisedCredentialsRiskConfiguration
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderRiskCo.abstract: The compromised credentials risk configuration object, including the EventFilter and the EventAction.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderRiskCo.name: lastModifiedDate
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderRiskCo.abstract: The date and time, in ISO 8601 format, when the item was modified.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderRiskCo.name: riskExceptionConfiguration
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderRiskCo.abstract: The configuration to override the risk decision.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderRevoke.name: clientId
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderRevoke.abstract: The client ID for the token that you want to revoke.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderRevoke.name: clientSecret
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderRevoke.abstract: The secret for the client ID. This is required only if the client ID has a secret.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderRevoke.name: token
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderRevoke.abstract: The refresh token that you want to revoke.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderRespon.name: authenticationResult
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderRespon.abstract: The result returned by the server in response to the request to respond to the authentication challenge.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderRespon.name: challengeName
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderRespon.abstract: The challenge name. For more information, see InitiateAuth.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderRespon.name: challengeParameters
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderRespon.abstract: The challenge parameters. For more information, see InitiateAuth.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderRespon.name: session
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderRespon.abstract: The session that should be passed both ways in challenge-response calls to the service. If the caller must pass another challenge, they return a session with other challenge parameters. This session should be passed as it is to the next RespondToAuthChallenge API call.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderRespon.name: analyticsMetadata
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderRespon.abstract: The Amazon Pinpoint analytics metadata that contributes to your metrics for RespondToAuthChallenge calls.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderRespon.name: challengeName
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderRespon.abstract:
The challenge name. For more information, see InitiateAuth.

ADMIN_NO_SRP_AUTH isn’t a valid value.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderRespon.name: challengeResponses
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderRespon.abstract:
The responses to the challenge that you received in the previous request. Each challenge has its own required response parameters. The following examples are partial JSON request bodies that highlight challenge-response parameters.

You must provide a SECRET_HASH parameter in all challenge responses to an app client that has a client secret.

SMS_MFA

"ChallengeName": "SMS_MFA", "ChallengeResponses": {"SMS_MFA_CODE": "[SMS_code]", "USERNAME": "[username]"}

PASSWORD_VERIFIER

"ChallengeName": "PASSWORD_VERIFIER", "ChallengeResponses": {"PASSWORD_CLAIM_SIGNATURE": "[claim_signature]", "PASSWORD_CLAIM_SECRET_BLOCK": "[secret_block]", "TIMESTAMP": [timestamp], "USERNAME": "[username]"}

Add "DEVICE_KEY" when you sign in with a remembered device.

CUSTOM_CHALLENGE

"ChallengeName": "CUSTOM_CHALLENGE", "ChallengeResponses": {"USERNAME": "[username]", "ANSWER": "[challenge_answer]"}

Add "DEVICE_KEY" when you sign in with a remembered device.

NEW_PASSWORD_REQUIRED

"ChallengeName": "NEW_PASSWORD_REQUIRED", "ChallengeResponses": {"NEW_PASSWORD": "[new_password]", "USERNAME": "[username]"}

To set any required attributes that InitiateAuth returned in an requiredAttributes parameter, add "userAttributes.[attribute_name]": "[attribute_value]". This parameter can also set values for writable attributes that aren’t required by your user pool.

In a NEW_PASSWORD_REQUIRED challenge response, you can’t modify a required attribute that already has a value. In RespondToAuthChallenge, set a value for any keys that Amazon Cognito returned in the requiredAttributes parameter, then use the UpdateUserAttributes API operation to modify the value of any additional attributes.

SOFTWARE_TOKEN_MFA

"ChallengeName": "SOFTWARE_TOKEN_MFA", "ChallengeResponses": {"USERNAME": "[username]", "SOFTWARE_TOKEN_MFA_CODE": [authenticator_code]}

DEVICE_SRP_AUTH

"ChallengeName": "DEVICE_SRP_AUTH", "ChallengeResponses": {"USERNAME": "[username]", "DEVICE_KEY": "[device_key]", "SRP_A": "[srp_a]"}

DEVICE_PASSWORD_VERIFIER

"ChallengeName": "DEVICE_PASSWORD_VERIFIER", "ChallengeResponses": {"DEVICE_KEY": "[device_key]", "PASSWORD_CLAIM_SIGNATURE": "[claim_signature]", "PASSWORD_CLAIM_SECRET_BLOCK": "[secret_block]", "TIMESTAMP": [timestamp], "USERNAME": "[username]"}

MFA_SETUP

"ChallengeName": "MFA_SETUP", "ChallengeResponses": {"USERNAME": "[username]"}, "SESSION": "[Session ID from VerifySoftwareToken]"

SELECT_MFA_TYPE

"ChallengeName": "SELECT_MFA_TYPE", "ChallengeResponses": {"USERNAME": "[username]", "ANSWER": "[SMS_MFA or SOFTWARE_TOKEN_MFA]"}

For more information about SECRET_HASH, see Computing secret hash values. For information about DEVICE_KEY, see Working with user devices in your user pool.

Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderRespon.name: clientMetadata
Classes/AWSCognitoIdentityProviderRespon.abstract:
A map of custom key-value pairs that you can provide as input for any custom workflows that this action triggers.

You create custom workflows by assigning Lambda functions to user pool triggers. When you use the RespondToAuthChallenge API action, Amazon Cognito invokes any functions that are assigned to the following triggers: post authentication, pre token generation, define auth challenge, create auth challenge, and verify auth challenge. When Amazon Cognito invokes any of these functions, it passes a JSON payload, which the function receives as input. This payload contains a clientMetadata attribute, which provides the data that you assigned to the ClientMetadata parameter in your RespondToAuthChallenge request. In your function code in Lambda, you can process the clientMetadata value to enhance your workflow for your specific needs.

For more information, see Customizing user pool Workflows with Lambda Triggers in the Amazon Cognito Developer Guide.

When you use the ClientMetadata parameter, remember that Amazon Cognito won’t do the following:

  • Store the ClientMetadata value. This data is available only to Lambda triggers that are assigned to a user pool to support custom workflows. If your user pool configuration doesn’t include triggers, the ClientMetadata parameter serves no purpose.

  • Validate the ClientMetadata value.

  • Encrypt the ClientMetadata value. Don’t use Amazon Cognito to provide sensitive information.
